title: FirstFT: Today's top stories
text:
Donald Trump's acquittal in his second Senate impeachment trial has triggered friction and recrimination within the Republican party between lawmakers who want to break from the former president and those who embrace his brand of politics.

Trump was acquitted on Saturday despite seven Republican senators voting to convict him of inciting an insurrection in last month's deadly assault on the US Capitol. The final 57-43 vote revealed a crisis within the Republican party over how to respond to their recent election losses.

After voting to acquit Trump, Senate minority leader Mitch McConnell hinted that the former president's legal woes were far from over. He echoed suggestions that Trump could face charges in criminal or civil courts relating to the January 6 siege.

“We have a criminal justice system in this country,” said the Senate minority leader on Saturday night. “We have civil litigation. And former presidents are not immune from being held accountable by either one.”

The US has not purged Trump from its public life, writes our editorial board. But through moral pressure, it can make a possible political comeback trickier. (FT)

Coronavirus digest

  • The White House and the UK called on China to hand over data from the early stages of the pandemic and expressed “deep concerns” about a World Health Organization fact-finding mission to Wuhan.

  • The US seven-day average of new Covid-19 cases on Sunday was 90,000, the first time it has been below six digits since November 2. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, meanwhile, has released its guidelines for how schools can reopen safely.

  • Boris Johnson said the UK had vaccinated more than 15m people as MPs pressured the government to lift the lockdown by the end of April. New rules come into force today in the UK, requiring residents returning from 33 high-risk “red-list” countries to quarantine in a hotel for 10-days on arrival.

  • Argentina's vice-president Cristina Fernández de Kirchner wants to postpone a $44bn debt deal with the IMF until the pandemic has eased.

  • Japan's Nikkei 225 stock index rallied past 30,000 points for the first time since 1990 on Monday as data showed the country's output grew 3 per cent in the fourth quarter of 2020. (FT)

History is crucial to understanding vaccine hesitancy among people of colour, writes Esan Swan. Follow the latest news on our live blog and our vaccine tracker has the latest on the global race to vaccinate.

In the news

Exclusive: Apple approached Nissan to work on car project Apple approached Japan's Nissan in recent months about a tie-up for its autonomous car project, according to people briefed on the matter. Talks between the Silicon Valley company and Kia, the affiliate of South Korea's Hyundai Motor, ended recently. (FT)

Texas begins blackouts as temperatures plunge The Texas grid operator began rolling blackouts early on Monday as arctic air enveloped the central US and sparked record demand for power. Freezing temperatures from Canada will send temperatures to 4F (minus 15.5C) in Dallas, forecasters said. (FT)

Reddit effect takes cannabis stocks on a wild ride Retail investors have poured more than $440m into cannabis stocks since the start of February, according to Vanda Research, after mentions on the Reddit forum that led to the recent price rise of GameStop. The chief executive of Reddit and Robinhood will testify this week at US congressional hearings, alongside leading Wall Street hedge fund managers. (FT)

Myanmar blacks out internet The country's military regime ordered internet providers to shut off service for eight hours on Monday morning and deployed troops and army vehicles on to the streets, raising fears of an imminent crackdown on a popular resistance movement against the coup. (FT)

Vivendi to spin out Universal Music Group The French media group is planning to spin out Universal Music Group, home to pop stars including Lady Gaga and Kanye West. Vivendi values the UMG, the world's biggest music company, at €30bn and plans to return much of the proceeds from the divestment directly to its shareholders. (FT)

Mexico's investment drought holds back recovery When Mexican president Andrés Manuel López Obrador swept to a landslide victory in July 2018, his government pledged to push public and private investment to 25 per cent of GDP. Instead, investment has fallen as a series of investor-unfriendly moves deterred inflows. (FT)

China's box office roars while Hollywood remains on mute China's box office was off to a roaring start during the crucial Lunar New Year holiday while the majority of cinemas remain closed in North America, underscoring the diverging fates of the world's two largest film markets. (FT)

Draghi sworn in Mario Draghi was sworn in as Italy's prime minister on Saturday, completing his transformation from central bank chief to frontline politician. The immediate task for the former president of the European Central Bank is to ensure the success of Italy's Covid-19 vaccination programme and contain the economic damage inflicted by the pandemic. (FT)

Catalan separatists bolster majority With 99 per cent of the vote counted, Catalonia's separatist parties strengthened their majority in the region's parliament in Sunday's elections, but the anti-independence Socialists won more votes than any other single party. (FT)

The days ahead

WHO vaccine recommendation The WHO is likely to issue an emergency use listing for the Oxford/AstraZeneca coronavirus vaccine this week, possibly as early as Monday. Hannah Kuchler and Clive Cookson answered your questions about vaccines on Friday. (FT)

Australia's Big Tech legislation Australian MPs will begin debating landmark legislation to force tech giants such as Google and Facebook to pay for news on Monday. (FT)

Eurozone finance ministers meet Finance ministers from the 19 states that use the euro meet in Brussels. (FT)

US financial markets are closed for the Presidents' Day holiday on Monday and China is shut until Thursday for the lunar new year.

What else we're reading

Bitcoin rise reflects America's decline The rise in the popularity of highly volatile cryptocurrencies such as bitcoin should be seen as a signal of a new world order in which the US and the dollar will play a less important role, writes Rana Foroohar. (FT)

Race to clean up the steel industry Skyscrapers, cars and cruise ships. All have one thing in common: steel. But the metal's role in the climate crisis is under closer scrutiny. From the American rustbelt to China's manufacturing heartlands, smelting iron pumps out huge quantities of carbon dioxide, the main contributor to man-made global warming. (FT)

Nigerian powerhouse to head WTO As Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala prepares to take up the role of director-general of the World Trade Organization, she has an opportunity for the organisation to rediscover its original purpose of raising living standards and to revamp its outdated rule book at a time of accelerating change. (FT)

Lunch with the FT: North Korean defector Tae Yong-ho “A very small spark” is all it would take to topple Kim Jong Un, the former North Korean diplomat told Edward White over lunch in South Korea, where he now resides. “[L]ike what happened at the Arab Spring.” (FT)

The struggle for women's rights in the Arab world Activists are trying to challenge predatory behaviour 10 years after regional uprisings raised hopes of substantial change. The horrific details of a woman who was allegedly raped at the luxury Fairmont hotel in Cairo in 2014 illustrate the obstacles in the path of change. (FT)

The ticking time bomb inside the new world of work In a post-coronavirus world, there is a looming “discrimination crisis” if workers are allowed to work at home as often as they please, writes Pilita Clark. Meanwhile, the shift to online learning has allowed workers to access “elite” corporate training cheaply and efficiently. (FT)

Are you a working parent? How has the pandemic affected you? We want to know how it has been for you. Your participation will be integral to an FT reporting project.

Podcast of the day

A rundown of the most important global business stories you need to know for the coming day, from the newsroom of the Financial Times. Today's episode looks at post-Brexit EU-UK data rules and asks whether current prices suggest a new commodities ‘supercycle'. (FT)
